At meeting of number Of young men Of
Wilmington, convened on "Wednesday 2Sd
inst. for the purpose of forming Society for
the suppression of Intemperance, Wm. A.
Mendenhall was called to the chair, and
Thomas M'Corklc was appointed Secretary.
The object of the Society being stated, the
following preamble and resolutions were a.
dopted.


When we view, as we now do. with mingled
feelings of pity and regret, that many OF our
fellow creatures, not only in the humble
walks of life, but even those enjoying more
elevated standing in society, both old and
young. have given themselves up to habitu-
al inebriation, by which they are bringing.
and many have already brought, upon them
selves disgrace and ruin, the nober feelings
of our nature resume their empire, and
mourn the deprayity of mankind


Intempcrance, with all its concomitant e.
Wis and miseries, is spreading distress. in
thousand forms, among the inhabitants of
our country-in,ruding itself upon connubial
feicity-on the social circle, and on every





species of domestic bliss and tranquility
shacklng and destroying the most noble
principles of man n-transfcrrins an honest
and virtuous mind to one depraved, vicious,
and neutrality-suspicious. not only power
ty and infamy, but host of morbid alice
tions; and furnishing catalogue of crimes,
which demand retributivc Justice by death.


1t is not cur desire to enter into detailed
view of all the baneful effects prou.lced by
this species of depravity; we would wi'h'
merely, to recount few Of its effects.


Believing that we clearly see the ehscts
which this evil is producing among us, we
feel it to be a DUTY which we owe to our
fellow creatures, to society and to GOD,
when an antidote is placed With" our reach'
to use our best endeavors to obtain it; and by
proper application. arrest intemperance
il IS progress, and ;f possible. snatch ito

victims from the brink Of ruin, aud again re.
store them to sober Afe. We believe that
the means for reclairning incorporate per-
sens can be obtained, and is now offered to
us by Doctor William Chambers, of the city
OF New-York-the efficacy of this medi-
cine has been sufficiently tested in the cure

RESOLVED, That the members of this
meeting form themselves into society for
the above purpose, to be called the Young
mems Society Of Wilmington, for the suf'-
hression Of fIntemherance.


Resolved, That Committee be appoint-
ed to draft Constitution and bylaws for the
government OF this Society, to be presented
at the next meeting.


Reso{ved, That two Committees be ap-
pointed for the purpose OF procuring men,
bers to this society, and to obtain their sigma
lures as such.


Resolved, That Archibald Robertson be
appointed reaSuTeT, lnto WHOSE IanuS All
donations, and money accruing from mem
bers, shall be paid.


Resolved. That so soon as sufficient
sum be raised, such sum shall be expended
in procuring the medicine of DR.. Chambers,
for the cure of Incorporate persons.


RESOLVED, That Thomas M'Corkle, Jas.
A. Sparks, and w. A. Mendenhall, be a con-
fdental Committee, who shall dispose of the
medicine, when procured, and shall OBJ
serve secrecy as 70 the name of the person
applying for it, unless otherwise instructed
by said applicant.


Resolved. That this meeting now adjourn
to meet again in the South wing ofthe Town
Hall, on Saturday evening next, (26th inst.)
at o'clock, where all persons desrous of
furthering the object Of the society are in
vited to attend.

A correspondent Of the. New York Amer
lean SAYS "that a new mineral spring about
two miles below the falls of Niagara, on the
American side, has attracted considerable
attention. The water OF this spring has
proved beneficial to several persons in Ill
health, who have visited it. A bottle ct i
has been brought to this city, and has been
tested by medical gentleman. He finds
that it contains sulphuric and muriatic acid,
magnolia, aud lime. This will be quite a
convenience to the company visiting the falls
ot Niagara. They can view the sublime
and beautiful scenes in that vicinity, and Al
the same time make use Of the healing and
salubrious waters Ct this fountain"

We learn that the u. S. frigate lava. Cap.
tain Crane, is to sail for the Mediterranean.

Of the squadron. The frgate Delaware is
also 20 be fitted ont shortly, it is said. under

A son ofMr. Polh amis, Of Marbleborough.
Ulster county. N. Y. aged five years, on the
22d of April last in playing on the preci-
pice of the falls of that place, fell tive hun
dred and seven fee. down among the rocks,
was carried by the stream about two hun
dred feet below the place where he fell,
and was there found the next morning alive,
on the opposite bank Of the creek. after lay
ing all night in the cold and rain. He has
since recovered. The highest perpendicu-
lar fall is about twenty-five feet. This fact
can be attcsted by the inhabitants of that vii
iage.

.4gf4l Eayratve-"I once in my early
days" says DIR. Currie. "hcard (for as it
was night could not see) a traveller drown
ing. not in the Amman itself, but in the firth
Of Soiway. close by the mouth Of the river.
The influx Of the tide had unhorsed him in
the night, as he was passing the sands of
Cumberland. The west wind blew a tenn
pest, and according to the common express
ion, brought in the water three foot abreast,
Ihc traveller got upon s,anding not lit
tie way from the shore. There he dashed
himself to the post. shouting for half an hour
for assistance, till the tide rose over his head.
In the darkness OF the night, and amidst the
pauses Of the hurricane, his voice, heard at
intervals was exqus!tely mournfui. No one
could go to his assistance--no enc knew
where he was---the sound seemed to proceed
from the spirit Of the waters. But morning
rosc---the tide had ebbcd--anl the poor
traveller was found lashel to the pole OF the
net, and bleaching in the wind.

William II. Tryon, was on Saturday con-
yicted in the New York Sessions on an in
dictment for a second offence After the
verdict was pronounced, the Recorder re-
marked that he really was a wonderful man


In April, 1920, he was sent to the Peni-
tentiary, in February, 1921, to the State
Prison; in april, 1894, again to the Peniten-
,iary; in 1926, for the third time, to the
Penitentiary; and on Saturday he will prob
ably regain his old quarters in the State Pris
on His age is 2l. aud he has served his
time ont in each case.

The annexed sweet efusion is from the
pen of S. G. &. BrainarG; Esq. editor Of the
Connectcu, Mirror. We do not recollect a
piece, on similar subject, that, in the
same space. combines such felicity of ex-
preston with such aptness and beauty of il
lustration.


EPITHALAMIUM
saw two clouds at morning,


Tng'd with the rising sun;
And in the dawn they foated on,


And mingled into one
Thought that morning clpud was bhst,
1t mov'd SO sweetly to tht west.
saw two summer currents


Flow smoothly to theirmceting,
And join their course with silent force,


In peace each other greeting;
Calm was their course through banks of green,
While dimpling eddies play'd between.
Such be your gentle motion.


Till life's last pulse shall beat;
Like summers beam, and summers stream,


Float on, in joy, to meet
A calmer sky, where storms shall cease
a purer sky, where all is peace,

Love qf Kao.uledge.-~hs striking in
stance of irresistible thirst for knowledge, 1t
is related Of the late Miss Eenger. whose
death in England was lately announced, that
when young, for want of bnuks, it was her
common practice to plant herself at the VIII
dow OF the only booksellers shop in the
country town where she resided, to read the
open pages of tAc new publications there
displayed, and to return again. day after day.
to examine whether by good fortune, fresh
leaf OF any Of them might have been turned
over.

Desertcrs-Within two or three days,
three bodies OF uhitcd States sailors, belong
ing to the sloop Of war Lexington, have
been found in the river. one with three shirts,
three pair Of pantaloons, two roundjackets,
and a tarpaulin hat, tied OH his head; another
with the same number of garments tied
round his waist, &c. 1t is supposed that they
were drowned in attempting to swim from
the ship, while she lay in the stream.

Few articles of living are more indispcnsahly
necessary in family, than good butter; and few
that arc more nauseous and unhealthy than bad
butter, and very great proportion otthe butter
brought to the market is bad. And much that is
called good is very bad when compared with
that which is really good. .-Tlis must, in great
degree, be owing to a want of knowledge IN
those who make it. If those who keep cows
would adopt the following method ofmaking but
ter, they would have more and better butter
than they can have in any other way. Let yoir
milk pals, pans, and churns, he always clean
and sweet; let the milk yon keep over night, be
churned with what you milk in the morning
while the latter is warm. In this way your but
ter will be sweet and if you work out the butter
milk and salt it well, it will be solid and good,
and command the highest price i'll market. Ma.
ny persons while churnng are in the habit OF
putting water into the churn, and also OF wash
ing their butter with water; this 's bad prac-
ticc, and should be avoided by all who wish their
butter to remain sWeet.--Hhacd ". a. J01rha!'


T;N1nr Nine valuable horses, belonging to
the Erie line of stages were poisoned IN Cieave-
land Ohio, last week, four of which died. On
examination, the appearance OF tile stomach ana
intestines, (says the Herald) strongly indicated
the presence Of corrosive sublimafe, and crcun'
stances warrant the suspicion that it was admin
istered designedly.


we stated a week or two since, ''that child
of one of our most respectable citiEens, had a
pin which had no doubt been swallowed, evil
IDENTIFY forcing its way through its breast" we
last week omitted to say, that what we stated 70
be pin, has proved to be pretty. large sized
common sewing needle. A slig,h incision was
made over the outer end of the needle, which
was was then readily drawn out with a pair of twee;
GERS. The child is perfectly well and appeared
to suffer but little by the operation. That the
needle had been swallowed by the child, we
think there is no reason whatever to doubt.

N,rg1 Honesty, They that neglect moral hon.
csty neglect that Which is great part Of rcl.
gion--their duty towards God, and their duty 60
wards man. What care to see a man run after
sermon, fhe cheat as soon as he comes home
On the other side, morality must not be without
religion; for if so, it may change, as suits his
convenience. Religion must govern it. He
that has no religion TO govern his morality, is no
better than my mastiif dog; SO long as you ca
rcss him, and please him, and not hurt him, he
will play with you as finely as may be- he is a
very good moral nastif' but ifyou hurt him he
viii fly in your face and tear out your throat.

The brig Thomas and William, from

The President and faculty os the Colun-
hian College, at Washington, having resign
ed, their station in consequence ot the great
pecuniary embarrassincnts ofthe institution,
the beard Of trustees have declared n vaca-
tion until the second Wednesday in s,eptcm-
ber next. They express hope that by
that time they win be able 10 procure q fac
ulty of tho highest qualifications, and to
recommenc" the operations Of the college
under mere favorable auspices.


William Werrall who died last winter in
PENNSYLVANIA, was born in Marble township,
II miles from Philadelphia in November,
1880. A friend has lately published some
"reminiscences collected from the old gentle
man short time befor his death. Among
others, Mr.. Wcrrel stated that he never
saw coffee or tea, until he was twenty years
of age. His father brought some tea from
Philadelphia; and his aunt, who lived with
them and had the charge Of the house, did
not know how to use it until she received in
formation from one of her most refined
neighbors. This prudent conduct was not
initiated by one of her incautiou friends,
who boiled the leaves and buttered them
! h1tcRlpcrdncc Efforts are MAKING III dlicreh'
parts of the country TO diminish the vice OF IN
temperance. Societies are forming, ministers
are preaching, and tracts publishing all Tor the
same purpose 1t s said that 10000 die annu'
ally of intemperance, and that 45,o0o,oo0 gal
Ions ofaidcnt spirits are consumed a year What
is the best mothod 10 diminish this vice. This ,i
the great question to be decided. The Frencl
are proverbially temperate people, SO far as re
CARDS drinking. The French too are the mos
gallant people in the world, and are devoted II
their attention to the iairsex. Is not this OH, o
the principal causes oftheiv temperate habits =
If SO, would not an increase and improvement
ofvirtuous intercourse amonS The sexes, be
gre,ter means of discouragng hard drinking
than all the sermons in the world Give females
their proper asccndcncy in ,ociety and they wll
have more effect in improving manners, and M
manizing feelings, than all shat male societies
can ever produce. In France, women mix
with every amusement, and almost cvery husi
ness National .4dpocate.

A gang has been detected in Painesville,

The physicians of Connecticut, have re-

isfied that the case is urgent.

Mr.. Grammer, in N. II. was sentenced to

He must take care in future how he conju-
gates his verbs.


In the late acquired territory for the peo-
plc of Georgia. there are. according to the
calculation of the surveyor general himself,
about 100000 acres of land and water
The greater part Of the whole territory is
good land and we'll waterel.

The New Orleans papers otthe 2lst Of
April. state that the steamboat Give Branch
was entirely destroyed by fire, with all her

damage OF consequence was sustained.


Ltrenzo Dow arrived at TusAmbia, Ala

At meeting of number Of young men Of
Wilmington, convened on "Wednesday 2Sd
inst. for the purpose of forming Society for
the suppression of Intemperance, Wm. A.
Mendenhall was called to the chair, and
Thomas M'Corklc was appointed Secretary.
The object of the Society being stated, the
following preamble and resolutions were a.
dopted.


When we view, as we now do. with mingled
feelings of pity and regret, that many OF our
fellow creatures, not only in the humble
walks of life, but even those enjoying more
elevated standing in society, both old and
young. have given themselves up to habitu-
al inebriation, by which they are bringing.
and many have already brought, upon them
selves disgrace and ruin, the nober feelings
of our nature resume their empire, and
mourn the deprayity of mankind


Intempcrance, with all its concomitant e.
Wis and miseries, is spreading distress. in
thousand forms, among the inhabitants of
our country-in,ruding itself upon connubial
feicity-on the social circle, and on every





species of domestic bliss and tranquility
shacklng and destroying the most noble
principles of man n-transfcrrins an honest
and virtuous mind to one depraved, vicious,
and neutrality-suspicious. not only power
ty and infamy, but host of morbid alice
tions; and furnishing catalogue of crimes,
which demand retributivc Justice by death.


1t is not cur desire to enter into detailed
view of all the baneful effects prou.lced by
this species of depravity; we would wi'h'
merely, to recount few Of its effects.


Believing that we clearly see the ehscts
which this evil is producing among us, we
feel it to be a DUTY which we owe to our
fellow creatures, to society and to GOD,
when an antidote is placed With" our reach'
to use our best endeavors to obtain it; and by
proper application. arrest intemperance
il IS progress, and ;f possible. snatch ito

Antisthenes wondered at mankind, that in
buying an earthen dish, they were careful

in choosing friends as to take them flowed
with vice.


Mr. segfried E. Walter. employed as
clerk and assistant in the school attached to
the Franklin Institute, last week, absconded

longing to the master, it being quarter day.

victims from the brink Of ruin, aud again re.
store them to sober Afe. We believe that
the means for reclairning incorporate per-
sens can be obtained, and is now offered to
us by Doctor William Chambers, of the city
OF New-York-the efficacy of this medi-
cine has been sufficiently tested in the cure
of about two thousand persons. DR.. Cham
bers, with truly philanth, opic mind, has
generously offered, through desire to CO.
operate with US in our laudable undertaking,
to dispose of his medicine to US, at reduc-
ed price. Therefore.


RESOLVED, That the members of this
meeting form themselves into society for
the above purpose, to be called the Young
mems Society Of Wilmington, for the suf'-
hression Of fIntemherance.


Resolved, That Committee be appoint-
ed to draft Constitution and bylaws for the
government OF this Society, to be presented
at the next meeting.


Reso{ved, That two Committees be ap-
pointed for the purpose OF procuring men,
bers to this society, and to obtain their sigma
lures as such.


Resolved, That Archibald Robertson be
appointed reaSuTeT, lnto WHOSE IanuS All
donations, and money accruing from mem
bers, shall be paid.


Resolved. That so soon as sufficient
sum be raised, such sum shall be expended
in procuring the medicine of DR.. Chambers,
for the cure of Incorporate persons.


RESOLVED, That Thomas M'Corkle, Jas.
A. Sparks, and w. A. Mendenhall, be a con-
fdental Committee, who shall dispose of the
medicine, when procured, and shall OBJ
serve secrecy as 70 the name of the person
applying for it, unless otherwise instructed
by said applicant.


Resolved. That this meeting now adjourn
to meet again in the South wing ofthe Town
Hall, on Saturday evening next, (26th inst.)
at o'clock, where all persons desrous of
furthering the object Of the society are in
vited to attend.


w. A. MENDENHALL Pres.
THOMAS M'CORKLE, Sec'ry.

We look at the appointment asa prompt

present crisis; and as evidence that he will

made to thwart and embarrass the govern

of age, who mounted up ladder into the burn

fthe window, into the court yard and descend
ed unhurt, and had them put into boat, while
her father, ignorant IF this heroic actions, cx

rather than expose Themselves 10 certain dcs
truction !, was not till she had Informed him Of
what she had done, that the workmcn renewed

Waters, tenant, has recovered in the

landlord entered the premises with his BALM

A correspondent Of the. New York Amer
lean SAYS "that a new mineral spring about
two miles below the falls of Niagara, on the
American side, has attracted considerable
attention. The water OF this spring has
proved beneficial to several persons in Ill
health, who have visited it. A bottle ct i
has been brought to this city, and has been
tested by medical gentleman. He finds
that it contains sulphuric and muriatic acid,
magnolia, aud lime. This will be quite a
convenience to the company visiting the falls
ot Niagara. They can view the sublime
and beautiful scenes in that vicinity, and Al
the same time make use Of the healing and
salubrious waters Ct this fountain"

We learn that the u. S. frigate lava. Cap.
tain Crane, is to sail for the Mediterranean.
in a few DAYS. to take the place of the ship
of the line North Carolina, Commodore Ro-
gers, which is expected home before long.
Capt e. will, of course, have the command
Of the squadron. The frgate Delaware is
also 20 be fitted ont shortly, it is said. under
junior Captain, to join the Mediterranean
squadron.


Captain Watson, of the Marine Corps,
has been transferred from the station at this
City, to the command Of the Marines at
Portsmouth, New Hampshire.

full articles.headline: REMARKABLE PROVIDENCE.
full articles.article:
A son ofMr. Polh amis, Of Marbleborough.
Ulster county. N. Y. aged five years, on the
22d of April last in playing on the preci-
pice of the falls of that place, fell tive hun
dred and seven fee. down among the rocks,
was carried by the stream about two hun
dred feet below the place where he fell,
and was there found the next morning alive,
on the opposite bank Of the creek. after lay
ing all night in the cold and rain. He has
since recovered. The highest perpendicu-
lar fall is about twenty-five feet. This fact
can be attcsted by the inhabitants of that vii
iage.

t!e !-sss. AZ. currents Of w.,esinto TIE bladder

rious nature


.4gf4l Eayratve-"I once in my early
days" says DIR. Currie. "hcard (for as it
was night could not see) a traveller drown
ing. not in the Amman itself, but in the firth
Of Soiway. close by the mouth Of the river.
The influx Of the tide had unhorsed him in
the night, as he was passing the sands of
Cumberland. The west wind blew a tenn
pest, and according to the common express
ion, brought in the water three foot abreast,
Ihc traveller got upon s,anding not lit
tie way from the shore. There he dashed
himself to the post. shouting for half an hour
for assistance, till the tide rose over his head.
In the darkness OF the night, and amidst the
pauses Of the hurricane, his voice, heard at
intervals was exqus!tely mournfui. No one
could go to his assistance--no enc knew
where he was---the sound seemed to proceed
from the spirit Of the waters. But morning
rosc---the tide had ebbcd--anl the poor
traveller was found lashel to the pole OF the
net, and bleaching in the wind.

William II. Tryon, was on Saturday con-
yicted in the New York Sessions on an in
dictment for a second offence After the
verdict was pronounced, the Recorder re-
marked that he really was a wonderful man


In April, 1920, he was sent to the Peni-
tentiary, in February, 1921, to the State
Prison; in april, 1894, again to the Peniten-
,iary; in 1926, for the third time, to the
Penitentiary; and on Saturday he will prob
ably regain his old quarters in the State Pris
on His age is 2l. aud he has served his
time ont in each case.

The annexed sweet efusion is from the
pen of S. G. &. BrainarG; Esq. editor Of the
Connectcu, Mirror. We do not recollect a
piece, on similar subject, that, in the
same space. combines such felicity of ex-
preston with such aptness and beauty of il
lustration.


EPITHALAMIUM
saw two clouds at morning,


Tng'd with the rising sun;
And in the dawn they foated on,


And mingled into one
Thought that morning clpud was bhst,
1t mov'd SO sweetly to tht west.
saw two summer currents


Flow smoothly to theirmceting,
And join their course with silent force,


In peace each other greeting;
Calm was their course through banks of green,
While dimpling eddies play'd between.
Such be your gentle motion.


Till life's last pulse shall beat;
Like summers beam, and summers stream,


Float on, in joy, to meet
A calmer sky, where storms shall cease
a purer sky, where all is peace,

From the Quebec Gazette.
SHIPWRECK OF THE ROB ROY.
full articles.article:
The following is extracted from a letter
from respectable source, dated the. Cd inst
at St. Jean, port Jolo, near the scene of the
wreck.


II have unfortunately just been a witness
Of trightful shipwreck. On the 30ta ult.,
at eleven o'clock at night, "A vessel from Bel
last with $50 settlers, stranded on the shoals
ttLislet. The people not knowing, in the
gloomy storm and darkness, where they
we're, and the pilot supposing that the yes
sci was on some uninhabited island or shoal
which the tide would cover did not land i'm
Medately. The tide rose, and the wind
which blew so violently that it has thrown
3 down many fences, trees and buildings in the
| nelghbourhood, soon drove the huge waves
over the vessel, giving it repeatedly heavy
shocks. saw them cut away IN the morn
ing both the masts, one after the other; and
when this failed, to relieve the vessel by
tightening her. the people in confusion and
Qismay hurried to the end of the bowsprit,
from which they prccipitated themselves in
70 the boats, which were of course unable
70 contain so large a number Most Of the IN
mad been exposed to the whole force of the
waves, and they were benumbed with cold :,
ana overpowe red by their distressing and
hopeless condition. Those who were left
on board were only landed on the 1st about
'nree o'clock III the afternoon. Of these


omc were dead and others dying There
''e az TINS moment seventeen dead bodies in
wy wy mouse, men, women and children, but
.a'eAy the latter. These will be inferred
w.'morrow.-At another house there are 2

!ore US.

."'ef w.. OF passengers was ISL; Of these


Ae drowned, 10 children women and 9


,sM ,ssn The Waterloo brought away 81 men


,,,0 ,,v,""nen, and 81 children-in all, 20 per-


,ss ne rest had proceeded to Quebec by


MY! Inc survivors were loud in their
ss s,ase OF the inhabitants Of the country near


Ss.'e they were wrecked, who treated
E Nsu "lth the utmost kindness, slaughter,ng
Z r,.a ,,n cattle to give them provisions. The
VIZ, ,ISSo the Rob Roy is valued at ESQ 900,
n,u m11 Is almost all lost or damaged. One
Il Nsu lost his wife and three children; ano-
Il w. i.. out OF four children lost three-the sur
K bs. deaf and dumb. A Mrs. Lamb lost


e,,v husband, one child and money, and prop


ST! n W ,,e amount of 700l., and is now with
MA, ,Ini'dren left destitute. The vessel is a
N,o wreck. One of the masts is driven
6asss the bottom, and at high water the
lin VI goods were floating about in the
h,slew surgical hwtrument. Delau, Junior,


rspnn1p, presented to the French Academy an i'll


art .' ~ oy which he states that he can, accord


ID ear eneumstances, either produce in the inter-


Yc,sss. currents OF air, calculated in great ma


sea s'lGr Of that cavity vacuum, which in other

Love qf Kao.uledge.-~hs striking in
stance of irresistible thirst for knowledge, 1t
is related Of the late Miss Eenger. whose
death in England was lately announced, that
when young, for want of bnuks, it was her
common practice to plant herself at the VIII
dow OF the only booksellers shop in the
country town where she resided, to read the
open pages of tAc new publications there
displayed, and to return again. day after day.
to examine whether by good fortune, fresh
leaf OF any Of them might have been turned
over.

Desertcrs-Within two or three days,
three bodies OF uhitcd States sailors, belong
ing to the sloop Of war Lexington, have
been found in the river. one with three shirts,

full articles.headline: TO BUTTER MAHEUS.
full articles.article:
Few articles of living are more indispcnsahly
necessary in family, than good butter; and few
that arc more nauseous and unhealthy than bad
butter, and very great proportion otthe butter
brought to the market is bad. And much that is
called good is very bad when compared with
that which is really good. .-Tlis must, in great
degree, be owing to a want of knowledge IN
those who make it. If those who keep cows
would adopt the following method ofmaking but
ter, they would have more and better butter
than they can have in any other way. Let yoir
milk pals, pans, and churns, he always clean
and sweet; let the milk yon keep over night, be
churned with what you milk in the morning
while the latter is warm. In this way your but
ter will be sweet and if you work out the butter
milk and salt it well, it will be solid and good,
and command the highest price i'll market. Ma.
ny persons while churnng are in the habit OF
putting water into the churn, and also OF wash
ing their butter with water; this 's bad prac-
ticc, and should be avoided by all who wish their

William Werrall who died last winter in
PENNSYLVANIA, was born in Marble township,
II miles from Philadelphia in November,
1880. A friend has lately published some
"reminiscences collected from the old gentle
man short time befor his death. Among
others, Mr.. Wcrrel stated that he never
saw coffee or tea, until he was twenty years
of age. His father brought some tea from
Philadelphia; and his aunt, who lived with
them and had the charge Of the house, did
not know how to use it until she received in
formation from one of her most refined
neighbors. This prudent conduct was not
initiated by one of her incautiou friends,
who boiled the leaves and buttered them
